TypeSignature.Value: public class ErrorProvider : System.ComponentModel.Component, System.ComponentModel.IExtenderProvider, System.ComponentModel.ISupportInitialize
.class public auto ansi beforefieldinit ErrorProvider extends System.ComponentModel.Component implements class System.ComponentModel.IExtenderProvider, class System.ComponentModel.ISupportInitialize

Docs.summary: Provides a user interface for indicating that a control on a form has an error associated with it.

remarks.format:
## Remarks ErrorProvider presents a simple mechanism for indicating to the end user that a control on a form has an error associated with it. If an error description string is specified for the control, an icon appears next to the control. The icon flashes in the manner specified by <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.BlinkStyle%2A>, at the rate specified by <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.BlinkRate%2A>. When the mouse hovers over the icon, a ToolTip appears showing the error description string.
Typically, you use ErrorProvider in association with data-bound controls. When using ErrorProvider with data-bound controls, you must specify the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.ContainerControl%2A>, either in the constructor or by setting the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.ContainerControl%2A> property.
> [!NOTE] > The ErrorProvider component does not provide built-in support for accessibility clients. To make your application accessible when using this component, you must provide an additional, accessible feedback mechanism.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates using the ErrorProvider class to notify the user of a data entry error. The example creates a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> that contains a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox> control, a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control, and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox> control, each validating its content, and an ErrorProvider for each control. The example sets error icon options using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.BlinkRate%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.BlinkStyle%2A> properties and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.SetIconAlignment%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.SetIconPadding%2A> methods. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.SetError%2A> method is called with or without appropriate error text during a controlâ€™s <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Validated> event, depending upon the content in the control.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.windows.forms.e_0_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/t-system.windows.forms.e_0_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.windows.forms.e_0_1.vb)]
The following code example shows how to use the ErrorProvider with a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataSource%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataMember%2A> to indicate a data error to the user.
[!code-cs[Classic ErrorProvider Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.windows.forms.e_0_2.cs)] [!code-cpp[Classic ErrorProvider Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/t-system.windows.forms.e_0_2.cpp)] [!code-vb[Classic ErrorProvider Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.windows.forms.e_0_2.vb)]

remarks.format: ## Remarks To avoid conflicts at run time that can occur when changing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataSource%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataMember%2A>, you should use BindToDataAndErrors instead of setting <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataSource%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataMember%2A> individually.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the rate at which the error icon flashes.
Docs.value: The rate, in milliseconds, at which the error icon should flash. The default is 250 milliseconds.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The error icon flashes at the specified rate. A value of zero sets <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.BlinkStyle%2A> to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorBlinkStyle>.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider> class to notify the user of a data entry error. The example creates a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> that contains a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox> control, a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control, and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox> control, each validating its content, and an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider> for each control. The example sets error icon options using the BlinkRate and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.BlinkStyle%2A> properties and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.SetIconAlignment%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.SetIconPadding%2A> methods. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.SetError%2A> method is called with or without appropriate error text during a control's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Validated> event, depending upon the content in the control.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.windows.forms.e_2_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.windows.forms.e_2_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.windows.forms.e_2_1.vb)]

Docs.exception: The value is less than zero.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating when the error icon flashes.
Docs.value: One of the values. The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The error icon flashes in the manner specified by the assigned <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorBlinkStyle> when an error occurs. Setting the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.BlinkRate%2A> to zero sets the BlinkStyle to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorBlinkStyle>.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider> class to notify the user of a data entry error. The example creates a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> that contains a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox> control, a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control, and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox> control, each validating its content, and an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider> for each control. The example sets error icon options using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.BlinkRate%2A> and BlinkStyle properties and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.SetIconAlignment%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.SetIconPadding%2A> methods. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.SetError%2A> method is called with or without appropriate error text during a control's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Validated> event, depending upon the content in the control.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.windows.forms.e_1_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.windows.forms.e_1_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.windows.forms.e_1_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void Clear() cil managed

Docs.summary: Clears all settings associated with this component.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Calling this method clears all property settings for this <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider>, restoring the properties to their default values. To clear the error message, call the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.SetError%2A> method and pass in <xref:System.String.Empty> for the <xref:System.String> value. This removes the error glyph from the specified <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control>.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Typically, this is the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> the data-bound controls reside on.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the list within a data source to monitor.
Docs.value: The string that represents a list within the data source specified by the to be monitored. Typically, this will be a .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The DataMember is a navigation string based on <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataSource%2A>.
To avoid conflicts at run time that can occur when changing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataSource%2A> and DataMember, you should use <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.BindToDataAndErrors%2A> instead of setting <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataSource%2A> and DataMember individually.
## Examples The following code example shows how to use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider> with a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataSource%2A> and DataMember to indicate a data error to the user.
[!code-cs[Classic ErrorProvider Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.windows.forms.e_3_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[Classic ErrorProvider Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.windows.forms.e_3_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[Classic ErrorProvider Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.windows.forms.e_3_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the data source that the monitors.
Docs.value: A data source based on the interface to be monitored for errors. Typically, this is a to be monitored for errors.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The DataSource is a data source that you can attach to a control and that you want to monitor for errors. DataSource can be set to any collection that implements <xref:System.Collections.IList>.
To avoid conflicts at run time that can occur when changing DataSource and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataMember%2A>, you should use <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.BindToDataAndErrors%2A> instead of setting DataSource and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataMember%2A> individually.
## Examples The following code example shows how to use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider> with a DataSource and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.DataMember%2A> to indicate a data error to the user. This code assumes you have created and populated a <xref:System.Data.DataSet> named `dataSet1` containing a <xref:System.Data.DataTable> named `dataTable1`. When you bind the <xref:System.Data.DataSet> to a control such as the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> control, errors specified through <xref:System.Data.DataRow> objects appear as error glyphs in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> control.
[!code-cs[Classic ErrorProvider Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.windows.forms.e_0_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[Classic ErrorProvider Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.windows.forms.e_0_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[Classic ErrorProvider Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.windows.forms.e_0_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance string GetError(class System.Windows.Forms.Control control) cil managed

Docs.param: The item to get the error description string for.
Docs.summary: Returns the current error description string for the specified control.
Docs.returns: The error description string for the specified control.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example uses the GetError method to check for an error before opening a file dialog box. To run this example, paste the following code into a form containing a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox> named `TextBox1`, an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.OpenFileDialog> named `OpenFileDialog1`, a button named `Button1`, and an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider> named `ErrorProvider1`. Ensure all events are associated with their event handlers.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.FileDialog#2](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.windows.forms.e_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.FileDialog#2](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.windows.forms.e_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.FileDialog#2](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.windows.forms.e_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance valuetype System.Windows.Forms.ErrorIconAlignment GetIconAlignment(class System.Windows.Forms.Control control) cil managed

Docs.param: The control to get the icon location for.
Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating where the error icon should be placed in relation to the control.
Docs.returns: One of the values. The default icon alignment is .

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance int32 GetIconPadding(class System.Windows.Forms.Control control) cil managed

Docs.param: The control to get the padding for.
Docs.summary: Returns the amount of extra space to leave next to the error icon.
Docs.returns: The number of pixels to leave between the icon and the control.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Many icons typically have extra space around their central images, so the padding value is only necessary if additional space is necessary. Padding values can be positive or negative. Negative values cause the icon to overlap the edge of the control. The default icon padding is 0.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the that is displayed next to a control when an error description string has been set for the control.
Docs.value: An that signals an error has occurred. The default icon consists of an exclamation point in a circle with a red background.

remarks.format: ## Remarks For best results, use an icon of the size 16 x 16 pixels. Specified icons are resized to be 16 x 16 pixels, if necessary.

Docs.exception: The assigned value of the is .

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig newslot virtual instance void OnRightToLeftChanged(class System.EventArgs e) cil managed

Docs.param: A that contains the event data.
Docs.summary: Raises the event.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Events](../Topic/Handling%20and%20Raising%20Events.md).
The OnRightToLeftChanged method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool RightToLeft { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the component is used in a locale that supports right-to-left fonts.
Docs.value: if the component is used in a right-to-left locale; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks When this property is set to true, the error icon appears to the left of the associated control and the ToolTip text is displayed in right-to-left order.

Docs.summary: Occurs when the property changes value.

remarks.format:
## Remarks For more information about handling events, see [Events](../Topic/Handling%20and%20Raising%20Events.md).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the RightToLeftChanged event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A?displayProperty=fullName> with <xref:System.Console.WriteLine%2A?displayProperty=fullName> or appending the message to a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox>.
To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider> named `ErrorProvider1`. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the RightToLeftChanged event.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#382](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/e-system.windows.forms.e_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#382](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/e-system.windows.forms.e_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: public void SetError (System.Windows.Forms.Control control, string value);
.method public hidebysig instance void SetError(class System.Windows.Forms.Control control, string value) cil managed

Docs.param: The control to set the error description string for.
The error description string, or or to remove the error.
Docs.summary: Sets the error description string for the specified control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If the length of `value` is greater than zero, then the error icon is displayed, and the ToolTip for the error icon is the error description text. If the length is zero or `value` is `null`, the error icon is hidden.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider> class to notify the user of a data entry error. The example creates a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> that contains a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox> control, a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control, and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox> control, each validating its content, and an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider> for each control. The example sets error icon options using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.BlinkRate%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.BlinkStyle%2A> properties and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.SetIconAlignment%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider.SetIconPadding%2A> methods. The SetError method is called with or without appropriate error text during a control's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Validated> event, depending upon the content in the control.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/c9e3fcd9-44a5-4623-a307-_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/c9e3fcd9-44a5-4623-a307-_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.ErrorProvider#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/c9e3fcd9-44a5-4623-a307-_1.vb)]
